p: Our LCA showed that in 2001–2005, Oregon’s net wood product emissions were 32.61 million tCO 2e ( Table S3), and 3.7-fold wildfire emissions in the period that included the record fire year ( 15) ( Fig. 2). In 2011–2015, net wood product emissions were 34.45 million tCO 2e and almost 10-fold fire emissions, mostly due to lower fire emissions. The net wood product emissions are higher than fire emissions despite carbon benefits of storage in wood products and substitution for more fossil fuel-intensive products. Hence, combining fire and net wood product emissions, the forest sector emissions averaged 40 million tCO 2e y −1 and accounted for about 39% of total emissions across all sectors ( Fig. 2 and Table S4). NECB was calculated from NEP minus losses from fire emissions and harvest ( Fig. 1). State NECB was equivalent to 60% and 70% of total emissions for 2001–2005 and 2011–2015, respectively ( Fig. 2, Table 1, and Table S4). Fire emissions were only between 4% and 8% of total emissions from all sources (2011–2015 and 2001–2004, respectively). Oregon’s forests play a larger role in meeting its GHG targets than US forests have in meeting the nation’s targets ( 16, 17).
